title: irans zombie angelina jolie lookalike ventilator coronavirus instagram
story: AN Angelina Jolie zombie lookalike in Iran is on a ventilator after contracting coronavirus while in jail for her social media posts. Sahar Tabar, , gained an Instagram following after posting dozens of photos edited to make her resemble the Hollywood A-lister, but last year was arrested on charges including blasphemy and encouraging youths to corruption.Eery pictures from her account show her wearing white and grey make-up and have been photoshopped to give her face and arms a gaunt and zombielike appearance.Last month, Iran released around , prisoners as part of an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus in the country.Lawyers for Tabar, whose real name is Fatemeh Khishvand, have argued that she should also be released, but the US-based Center for Human Rights in Iran said that a request for bail was denied by a judge.Tabar has now contracted the coronavirus in prison, and is thought to be on a ventilator.Speaking on Wednesday, human rights lawyer Payam Derafshan said: We find it unacceptable that this young woman has now caught the coronavirus in these circumstances while her detention order has been extended during all this time in jail.Iran has faced increasing scrutiny over its handling of the crisis, and yesterday its own parliament acknowledged that the actual death toll is likely to be twice as high as the official count, currently ,.Derafshan added that authorities have even tried to deny that Tabar has caught the coronavirus.It makes no sense to deny this, he said.The prison director should acknowledge the infection and admit she has been hospitalized.He went on to say that all prisoners who were detained on non-violent charges should also be let out of jail as a response to the pandemic.Tabar was arrested in October by Irans Guidance Patrol, a part of law enforcement in the country tasked with arrested people, mostly women, deemed not to be following strict conservative dress codes.As well as blasphemy and the corruption of youth, the charges against her included the incitement of violence and gaining income through inappropriate means.Following her arrest, she was interviewed on state television and expressed regret over the posts, though many felt she had been coerced into the appearance.My mother was telling me to stop, but I didnt listen, she said.Sometimes the words of a stranger or a friend can be more important than those of a parent.One twitter user wrote: What does Sahar Tabar have to confess to Are there any principled people in parliament to put an end to the broadcasting of dirty and immoral confessions in television The coronavirus has infected over . million people and and killed almost , since breaking out in December.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The government’s strategy for an exit from coronavirus lockdown is ‘in limbo’ while Boris Johnson is off sick, Keir Starmer has claimed. The Labour leader said ministers are failing to take decisions on when and how tothe UK to normal le - and suggested the government has not acted “quickly enough” throughout the crisis.Mr Starmer has been calling for the government to set out details of how the government plans to release the UK from lockdown.Mr Starmer told the BBC’s Coronavirus Podcast: “I think that throughout this theyaposve struggled with taking decisions quickly enough.“The other factor though, I think, is we all know that the Prime Minister has been in hospital. “Weaposve all been pleased to see that heaposs come out and is feeling better. And it feels as though theyaposve been in a position probably for a week or  days now where itaposs been dficult for the Government to make big decisions. And I think thereaposs a bit of that lying behind this as well.  He added: “I suspect, although I donapost know, that Dominic Raab is just reluctant - he probably does know that itaposs time for an exit strategy - but heaposs probably reluctant to sign it off without the Prime Minister and I think thereaposs a bit of that in the mix.”Asked about Mr Starmer’s comments, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: “I don’t know that that’s fair. I think we’re all right now struggling with unprecedented circumstances, and we’re trying to plot a way through it.” But she added the Prime Minister’s convalescence “doesn’t make it any easier.” Transport Secretary Grant Shapps branded the claim “completely untrue”.He said: I was surprised to see that being said for the simple reason that yesterday alone I attended cabinet, I attended the Cobra [meeting]...I attended two or even three of the cabinet subcommittees that are making all of the day to day decisions.Itaposs simply not the case that everythingaposs on standstill. There would be no dference to those decisions because we have been guided by, as I keep saying, the scientists and the medical advice, whether or not the PM had been in the room or not in the room in this instance because this is a disease which does not look to politicians to decide how to respond, it responds to science.So thataposs not the case at all and I hope we can continue withy the very impressive cross-party and indeed national effort with this virus and not turn it into those kind of discussions. In a statement released last night, Mr Starmer welcomed First Secretary of State Dominic Raab’s announcement that the lockdown would continue for at least another three weeks.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain will be in lockdown for at least six weeks after restrictions were doubled today by the government. Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in Dominic Raab confirmed the drastic measures will go on another three weeks, until May  at the earliest. That means police can still fine groups of two or more people for gathering outside, unless theyaposre from the same household. And you can only leave home with a reasonable excuse - shopping for necessities, exercise once a day, a medical need or work where you have to. But todayaposs extension doesnapost mean that the lockdown will end on May . Mr Raab said the overallof the lockdown could be around three months and warned it might only be adjusted rather than lted altogether. That means while schools may reopen in May or June, working from home could continue for a year. So what does todayaposs decision mean - and how and when might the government start shting restrictions in the next few weeks  Hereaposs what you need to know.How long is the UKaposs lockdown extension  The UK coronavirus lockdown has legally been extended until it is next up for review, on May .  According to the Health Protection Regulations , Health Secretary Matt Hancock must review the emergency powers every three weeks.  Does this mean the lockdown ends on May   No. You should not look at the three-week extension and think that means it will all be over in three weeks. May  was only chosen because that is theof time for each review period, stated by the law. The government can announce on May  that it is extending the lockdown - either wholly or partly - for another three weeks. Or technically the government can choose to review the measures before three weeks are up . In other words, the May  date is totally arbitrary - despite the fact it sits conveniently just before the May  VE Day bank holiday.  When will the lockdown end  Dominic Raab warned the lockdown could go on for around three months in total. Askedit would take three weeks or three months for restrictions to be eased, he said: “The Prime Minister said at the outset that it would take three months to come through the peak - and I think that broadly is still the outline.” He said government advisors SAGE will review the latest lockdown extension by the end of the month. We simply donapost know yet though. The lockdown can only end when the UK is well past the peak of coronavirus cases and deaths. Government advisors believe we may now be at that peak or slightly past it, but itaposs too early to say. If we lt too early the virus will run rampant, says Health Secretary Matt Hancock.   How will the lockdown end   The lockdown is very unlikely to be lted in one go. It will be removed a little bit of the time to prop up the economy while protecting peopleaposs lives. Mr Raab was careful to focus on “adjustments” to the lockdown rather than axing it, and said we may eventually transition out of where we are. When there is a change, he said, it could involve relaxing measures in some areas while strengthening measures in other areas. Chief Scientic Advisor Sir Patrick Vallance said some measures may have to continue until we have a vaccine - which could be a year away. He said: There may be a number of measures that need to continue in order to allow [the virus] to be suppressed and controlled whilst vaccines and therapeutics come along.  What is the government looking for to end the lockdown  Dominic Raab set out five tests that the evidence must show before lting any lockdown. The government needs to be convinced that:The NHS is able to cope There is a sustained and consistent fall in death Infections are decreasing to manageable levels Testing and PPE numbers are adequate across the country Any adjustment wonapost risk a second peak of infectionsIn what ways might restrictions be lted  Travel to outdoor spacescould be one of the first restrictions lted - as long as social distancing is properly adhered to. And schools could re-open as it is vital they take the strainparents are to go back to work. But visiting loved ones in care homes could be off the table for some time, as could reopening pubs and restaurants. And chief scientic advisor Sir Patrick Vallance indicated working from home may be one thing that has to stay in place until we get a vaccine.Ministers are looking at a range of options. Itaposs understood theyaposre considering a plan to let younger people out of lockdown earlier than older people, because they are generally less at risk and prop up the economy. Ministers are also looking at plans to reopen coffee shops or hair salons, for example, by broadening the current list of essential shops. And they are looking at the idea of a phasedto school, with classrooms outside worst-hit London and Birmingham reopening earlier than in the cities. But no final decisions have been taken.

Dominic Raab said the broad outline is it will still take around three months from mid-March to come through the peak of the virus.Government advisors have warned the lockdown cannot be lted until the UK is well past the peak. The First Secretary of State signalled that even when restrictions change, they are unlikely to be lted altogether all in one go. Instead he focused on what he called “adjustments” to the lockdown. Mr Raab told the daily No press conference: It could involve relaxing measures in some areas while strengthening measures in other areas. It came as the lockdown was extended by its first legally-required three week period to May . Government advisors SAGE will review the latest lockdown extension by the end of the month. But Mr Raab gave no signal they would be eased or lted altogether at that point. Askedit would take three weeks or three months for restrictions to be eased, he said: “The Prime Minister said at the outset that it would take three months to come through the peak - and I think that broadly is still the outline.” Mr Raab emphasised the UK could transition out of lockdown rather than just ending it. He said: “We’ve been very clear that we’ll take the right decisions at the right moments based on the evidence. And they may well involve a transition out of the current measures.” Boris Johnson introduced the strict curbs on le in the UK on  March, as the government sought to limit the spread of the virus.Ministers are required by law to assess whether the rules are working, based on expert advice, every three weeks.And today after meeting the government’s scientic advisors SAGE and the COBRA emergency committee, the First Secretary of State confirmed that Britainaposs lockdown would continue for  three   weeks.Any change would have to go through the government’s scientic advisors SAGE and the COBRA emergency committee. The extension means that the lockdown will be assessed again on May , raising hopes that the lockdown may be lted by VE Day on May .But a top scientist warned that the UK must keep a signicant level of social distancing until a vaccine for coronavirus is found. Prof Neil Ferguson told the BBC there was little leeway to relax measures without something... in their place - such as testing and contact tracing. Britain’s coronavirus death toll has risen to more than , after  more deaths were reported in the last  hours. Another  patients died in hospitals in England. Scotland reported  new deaths as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said there were fresh signs the lockdown was working, but also warned: “We are by no means through this yet.” Wales reported  more deaths and  were recorded in Northern Ireland. The death toll stood at , on Wednesday. Despite agreeing to this extension there are believed to be extensive ides inside the Cabinet, with Treasury ministers warning that the economic impact of an extended closure could create a nightmare scenario for the British economy. Earlier this week the Office for Budget Responsibility said that the economy could shrink by %the lockdown lasted three months. To aid the fightback the government is rapidly trying to expand its testing facilities - with a pledge to reach , tests a day by the end of the month. It is also developing a mobile app which could make contact tracing easier - but only% of smartphone users download it when it is available. But the government has missed its target to reach , coronavirus tests a day as more than half of capacity lies unfilled. A statement on March  said testing would be ramped up to , a day “within four weeks” - which came to an end yesterday. But as of am yesterday, , tests had been carried out in Britain in the previous  hours. At no point has the number topped ,. That is despite Downing Street saying today that total daily testing capacity is now over ,. A silver lining emerged after it was suggested that schools outside coronavirus hotspots such as London and Birmingham may open as soon as next month. Ministers are considering proposals to open some primary and nursery schools away from the big cities from May, The Times has reported. Healthy young adults couldto work and children would head back to school under the plans.

The Duchess of Cambridge said extra recognition for the hardworking lesavers at the forefront of the crisis is the one of the main positives that you can take from this. The senior royal was speaking to the BBCaposs Tina Daheley alongside Prince William about a new phase of the government campaign Every Mind Matters. The Public Health England scheme is focused on looking after peopleaposs mental wellbeing during the Covid- pandemic. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.A video narrated by the Cambridges is set to be broadcast across national TV channels and social media from Monday, April . With the words “we’re in this together”, the couple herald the campaign which includes new NHS expert tips and advice on looking after mental wellbeing and supporting your family and loved ones during the crisis. In the interview, which broadcast this morning, Ms Daheley asks William: How are you helping get the message out there with Every Mind Matters  The duke said the scheme - which is in its second guise following feedback from the NHS and ious case studies - is now more important than ever in the current climate in guiding people on their mental health.We felt very strongly that now more than ever this was a vital tool and a vital service that people could easily access at home to guide them and give them just some very basic tips to mind their mental health, to mind their mental wellbeing through this process, he said. I think again staying connected, staying positive and being able to talk to friends and family is so crucial and having just some tips and some ideas as to how to tackle some of these strange feelings and dficult circumstances we’re finding ourselves in is really important.  Just to nudge us through these next few weeks, he added.William went on to say while NHS workers are used to dealing...with very sad situations the scale and speed of the current crisis in hospitals will be taking its toll on their mental health. He said for doctors and nurses having to see patients dying with no family members around them must be very dficult. They are there right next to the bedsides, looking after and caring for each and every patient in a critical condition and I think they take away that pain and that sometimes that fear and loneliness that these patients have to go through.  They’re the ones who absorb that and take it home to their families and I think again...that happening to somebody is not normal and we’re not superhuman any of us.So, to be able to manage those emotions and that feeling is going to take some time after all this is over as well, added the prince. Ms Daheley asked Kate: Do you think this will fundamentally change who we are and what we value  The duchess said absolutely, adding that the country is now seeing that frontline workers are doing the most extraordinary job and thataposs really coming to the forefront. I think it’s going to dramatically change how we all value and see our frontline workers and I think that is one of the main positives that you can take from this. They do an extraordinary job, it goes unrecognised daily and now I think all of us as a nation can really see how hard they work and how vital their work is, she added. The campaign has been updated after new data shows over  in  Brits are worried about the effect that coronavirus is having on their le, with over half saying it was affecting their well-being. The original launched last October with a similar video involving William and Kate and featuring Prince Harry and Meghan, before they quit the royal family.

MPs were also told that healthcare staff are #xCgenuinely concerned#xD about the safety of patients being compromisedworkers are spread too thinly.:Prince William admits he worries about health of senior royalsThe Duke of Cambridge has confessed he was worried when the Prince of Wales was diagnosed with Covid- and says the family are doing #xCeverything we can#xD to protect the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh.Talking about his father, who suffered from mild symptoms of Covid- and recovered after a period of self-isolation, William told the BBC: #xCI have to admit at first I was quite concerned, he fits the profile of somebody, at the age he#xs at, which is, you know, fairly risky, and so I was a little bit worried. #xCBut my father has had many chest infections, colds and things like that over the years and so I thought to myselfanybody#xs going to be able to beat this it#xs going to be him.#xDThe duke said he was reassured by doctors and friends who advised him by the time Charles reported his symptoms he was #xCprobably past the worst of it#xD, and his mind was put at rest after speaking to his father but at his age of  #xCyou do worry a bit more#xD.William said: #xCAnd obviously I think very carefully about my grandparents - who are the age they#xre at, we#xre doing everything we can to make sure that they#xre isolated away and protected from this. #xCBut it does worry me, what#xs going to happen to a lot of the vulnerable, high-risk people who are going potentially to have to isolate away for quite some time.#xD:We will follow the science to establish which drugs workMatt Hancock said that the UK will follow the science to establish which drugs work against coronavirus. Committee chairman Jeremy Hunt had askeda drugwas concluded to be safe, whether the UK would #xCshortcut#xD the normal processes in order to put orders in and get it out quickly. Mr Hancock said: #xCThe principles are that of course we want to get the very best treatment to the people who need them and we will follow the science. #xCAnd the science is best supported by having rigorous analysis of which drugs work and thus far there have not been any clinical trials that I am aware of around the world that have conclusively proved the value of these dferent drugs. #xCHowever, we have started to use them on patients here in the UK because the early evidence, which is not veried evidence, shows that they have some value. #xCBut all drugs also have downsides and so the approach we#xve taken here is that yes, to get people access to these drugs, but to do it within the structure of trials to make sure that we also get the evidence of what works.#xD:Matt Hancock will look at guidance around PPE in care homesMr Hancock indicated that he would look at the guidance around PPE for those working in care homes. Committee chairman Jeremy Hunt asked why the Government guidance does not require PPE to be worn in care homes for non-Covid patients andit was suggested that a risk is being taken with residents in care homes. Mr Hancock responded: #xCSo I do not think we#xre taking a risk in that way with residents in care homes. I#xm very happy to look at that particular point in the guidance. #xCI can see why people might read that as an inconsistency and I#xm very happy to take that away.#xD :Drinking alcohol makes people more vulnerable to coronavirus, WHO warnsA new report is urging the public to limit its alcohol intake amid the coronavirus pandemic.The report, by the World Health Organisation, has warned that drinking alcohol could make any coronavirus symptoms worse.It explained: #xCAt times of lockdown during the COVID- pandemic, alcohol consumption can exacerbate health vulnerability, risk-taking behaviours, mental health issues and violence.#xCWHO Europe reminds people that drinking alcohol does not protect them from COVID-, and encourages governments to enforce measures which limit alcohol consumption.#xDOur full story is here. :Italian police investigate coronavirus care home massacreItalian police are investigating Milan#xs largest care home where  people have died during the coronavirus pandemic.On Wednesday officers seized documents connected to Pio Albergo Trivulzio, which is home to , residents, to find out whether staff negligence contributed to the deaths.The scenes at the care home have been met by national outcry in Italy.The manager of the care home is under investigation amid allegations that no safety precautions were adopted.It has been alleged that staff were not allowed to wear masks - at least during the early stages of the outbreak - in case they alarmed residents.Alessandro Azzoni, whose -year-old mother, Marisa, is in the home, told:#xCthe situation in the home is completely out of control#xD.The home denies wrongdoing, claiming there were simply not enough testing kits for its , residents.#xCThe rules regarding masks were followed,#xD a spokeswoman of Pio Albergo Trivulzio told CNN, before claiming the deaths were in line with the same period last year.Click here for the full story. :Coronavirus care home death toll to be published very shortlyThe number of deaths from coronavirus in care homes will be published #xCvery shortly#xD, Health Secretary Matt Hancock has promised.The Care Quality Commissionbegan collecting data on deaths linked to Covid- which occurred in both hospitals and care homes on Thursday, the minister said.The most recent figures are of  care home deaths registered up until April , published on Tuesday by the Office for National Statistics .Click here for our story in full. :I would love to have PPE fall from the sky - Matt HancockMatt Hancock said #xCI would love to have PPE fall from the sky#xD as he was grilled this morning. The UK Health Secretary said: #xCI would love to be able to wave a magic wand and have PPE fall from the sky in large quantities and be able to answer your question about when shortages will be resolved. #xCBut given that we have a global situation in which there is less PPE in the world than the world needs, obviously it#xs going to be a huge pressure point.#xD He added: #xCThere#xs nothing that I can say at this select committee that will take away the fact that we have a global challenge and we#xre doing everything we can to resolve it to get that PPE to the front line.#xD :UK Health Secretary admits country is tight on gownsMatt Hancock has admitted the UK is #xCtight on gowns#xD but that , more are due to arrive today. Asked whether reports that some NHS trusts do not have enough gowns to get them through the weekend, Mr Hancock said: #xCAs of this weekend we will have shipped  billion items of personal protective equipment across the UK - so this is a... I#xve called it a Herculean effort before, it is a massive undertaking.#xCAnd it is understanding in a massive undertaking like that that there are complications and that there are challenges and I take responsibility for getting PPE out to everyone.#xD He added: #xCWe are tight on gowns, that is the pressure point at the moment. We have another , gowns arriving today and we#xre working on the acquisition internationally of more gowns, but it is a challenge. #xCAnd this follows changing the guidance  days ago which increased the advice on the use of gowns but also said that they should be used for sessional use rather than for inidual patient use. #xCAnd it is a big challenge delivering against that new guidance and we#xre doing everything we possibly can.#xD :Couples are likely to delay marriage, report saysCouples are likely to delay getting married in the wake of coronavirus, as by the time social distancing rules are lted it might be too late in the year for many weddings to happen, according to a report. Law firm Boodle Hatfield said couples were already deciding to marry later in le as more women were waiting until they were well established in their careers. The delay has led to the average age gap between men and women at marriage narrowing to . years, down from . years in , it was suggested. Emily Brand, a partner at Boodle Hatfield, said: #xCIt wouldn#xt be surprising to see a lot of couples delay marriages in the wake of coronavirus. Gearing up for a wedding can be an enormous undertaking requiring months of planning. #xCBy the time social distancing rules are lted, we might be too late in the year for many weddings to happen. #xCAdd in the financial burden caused by furloughs and job losses, and a lot of people might decide getting married in  is a better option.#xD:Number of NHS staff whove come forward to be tested is lower than expectedMr Hancock said that the number of NHS staff who have come forward to be tested for the virus has been lower than expected. He said: #xCWithin the NHS, the number of staff coming forward for testing is lower than was anticipated. #xCYou#xll understand why we had a priority order for the use of the test where it was patients first, then NHS staff. #xCFrankly, the number of NHS staff coming forward wasn#xt as high as expected and therefore we extended it very quickly both to residents and staff in social care. #xCBut because capacity is going up sharply, I#xm therefore able to expand it further and we#xll expand it again as soon as the capacity is there to make sure that that capacity is used up.#xD:Primark donates , items to Nightingale hospitalPrimark is donating thousands of products to London#xs new NHS Nightingale Hospital to help the nation fight the le-threatening coronavirus.Care packs containing around , items are being donated to the hospital, as numbers continue to rise in the UK.The donation is in response to calls for essential items from the NHS and is being accompanied by similar initiatives in other countries where Primark trades such as Ireland, Italy, Spain and the US.The packs contain underwear, leggings, T-shirts, footwear and towels and will be used by medical staff who are frequently working back-to-back shts or away from home, as well as patients who need a change of clothes or toiletries.Click here toon this. :There is capacity for , more tests, Matt Hancock saysMr Hancock said there is currently capacity for , more tests to be carried out. #xCWe have capacity for , more tests a day than we did yesterday which I find, given the pressures on testing, is frustrating,#xD he said. Asked by Science and Technology Committee chairman Greg Clark whether asymptomatic health workers should be routinely tested, Mr Hancock said: #xCThis is something that we are looking at. #xCThe asymptomatic transmission of Covid- is one of the novel features of it, it is not typical amongst coronaviruses and is one of the single most dficult things that has caused this pandemic to be so severe across the world. #xCThe answer to your question very precisely is yes that is something that we#xre looking at and I#xm talking to hospital chief executives about.#xD He said he could give a response with actions #xCin the coming weeks#xD.:UK government will build up contact tracing teamsMr Hancock said the Government would be building up contact tracing teams as part of the #xCtest, track and trace#xD strategy. He told the committee: #xCThat brings together teams from NHSX, who are leading on the app, with a huge array of partners that are working within that, from Public Health England, who are the experts on what we refer to as external contact tracing. #xCThe app is itself a contact tracing app, that is the point of it, is to be able to assist iniduals to do contact tracing themselves by notying people who they have been in close contact with when they have downloaded the app. #xCAnd then of course link that to testing, so people can get the tests.#xD :Swiss government plans gradual easing of restrictions from April The Swiss death toll from coronavirus has reached , people, the country#xs public health agency said on Friday, rising from , on Thursday. The number of people showing positive tests for COVID- increased to , from ,, it said.The government plans gradual easing of restrictions to curb the epidemic#xs spread from April , starting with the opening of hairdressers and nail bars.:Matt Hancock describes the expansion to testingMatt Hancock said: #xCNow we#xve got the curve under control, I want to be able to get back to the position that we can test everybody with symptoms and I anticipate being able to do that relatively soon because we#xre increasing capacity as I say. #xCI can now give you the full figures for yesterday - at midday yesterday, we#xd done , tests in the previous  hours, , from pillar one, , from pillar two, and  from pillar four. #xCSo I know history of testing is going to be a long debated subject. What really matters is what we#xre going to do from here on in. #xCAnd what I can tell you is that today we are able to expand the eligibility for testing which is currently for patients, for surveys and for NHS and social care staff, and some that go to LRFs for local urgent need. #xCI can today expand the eligibility for testing to police, the fire service, prison staff, critical local authority staff, the judiciary and DWP staff who need it and we#xre able to do that because of the scale-up of testing.#xDClick here to read our developing story.:Government had considered London-specic lockdown before nationwide measuresMr Hancock told the committee that the Government had considered a #xCLondon-specic lockdown#xD before implementing the measures nationwide. #xCWe did consider having a London-specic lockdown, and decided that it was better to do it across the country as a whole,#xD the Health Secretary said. #xCAnd that#xs for two reasons. The first is thatyou put a lockdown in one part of the country, then there#xs still travel from there to the rest of the country, so it isn#xt as easy as that. #xCAnd the second reason is that actually one of the really strong things that#xs come through this crisis is that the country is acting in lockstep.#xD He said that the country had #xCcome together#xD in response to the social distancing measures. #xCTo separate off one part of the country from the rest actually has downsides in terms of the national unity that we#xve seen in support for the overall response,#xD he added.:KEY EVENTTesting expanded to police, fire and prison servicesMatt Hancock says the eligibility for testing will be expanded to police, fire and prison services, critical local authority workers, the judiciary and DWP staff who need it.He said he had also expanded testing to social care staff and more residents in social care. He said mass community testing is part of the government strategy and they will introduce it when they can. :Lag in publication of overall death toll due to data collection issueMr Hancock said that the reason for there being a lag in the ONS publication of overall death numbers is due to a data collection issue. Asked by former health secretary Jeremy Hunt why only hospital deaths are being reported on a daily basis, he said: #xCSo the overall goal here is to be as transparent as possible and the quality of the data is the critical part to this question. #xCSo we have daily reports of deaths from Covid- or people with Covid-, whether it#xs deemed by the clinicians as the direct cause of somebody dying with Covid-. #xCWe have that in daily reports that come in through the four NHSs in the four nations and come into a central point and are then published.#xCThe data of deaths of people who have Covid- and die outside of hospitals takes longer to collect and that#xs because it is recorded on death certicates and death certicates are often written a couple of days after a death, they#xre not always written at the same time as the death, and then they#xre registered and go into the registry and then the data can be published. #xCSo the reason that the ONS publishes with a lag the overall number of deaths, as opposed to deaths in hospital, it is a data collection issue.#xD :Irans coronavirus death toll rises by  to ,Iran#xs death toll from coronavirus rose by  in the past  hours to reach , on Friday, health ministry spokesman Kianush Jahanpur said on state TV. The total number of cases of infection reached ,, of which , were in critical condition, he said. A parliamentary report released earlier this week said the coronavirus death toll might be almost double the figures announced by the health ministry, and the number of infections eight to  times more. Iran is the Middle Eastern country worst-affected by COVID- and has one of the world#xs highest death tolls.:The number of Covid- deaths in care homes is higher than reportedMr Hancock said that he has a #xChigh degree of confidence#xD that the number and proportion of Covid- deaths in care homes is higher than reported. Former health secretary Jeremy Hunt said: #xCYou talked about the ONS, they say that there have been  Covid deaths in care homes to date. #xCNow, Scotland thinks a quarter of its Covid deaths are in care homes, France, Italy, Spain think it#xs about half their Covid deaths in care homes. #xCDoes it really seem likely to you that less than % of our Covid deaths are in care homes #xD Mr Hancock responded: #xCNo, and the figure that you mention is a figure from a couple of weeks back and so I#xm absolutely sure that both the number and the proportion are... I can say with a high degree of confidence that the number and the proportion are higher than that you say and I#xll wait for the official statistics to understand it.#xD Matt Hancock being questioned by MPs :Inside the high speed trains transferring critically ill coronavirus patientsA high speed train has been used to ferry critically ill patients across France to free up intensive care beds.As the country continues to treat tens of thousands of Covid- patients, French medical authorities have commandeered TGV trains to transport the critically ill to less busy hospitals.The rail network is best known for the incredibly high speeds its trains hit as they surge through the French countryside.On Friday, April  the drivers were ordered to keep to a slower pace when  coronavirus patients were loaded on board.Instead of the usual bustling stations at Paris#x Austerlitz station, the two trains were met by a long line of ambulances, stretchers and medical staff.The full article is here. The medics and staff were squeezed on board the trains :, NHS workers have now been tested for coronavirusMr Hancock said that more than , NHS workers have now been tested for coronavirus. #xCI can tell you that over , people that work in the NHS have now had tests,#xD he said. Pushed on whether he has an estimate for the number of health workers who have been infected, he added: #xCNo I don#xt. What I have is an estimate of the proportion who are off work because they either have suspected Covid- or a household member does, which is a little over %. #xCAnd obviously with the expansion of testing we hope to be able to get that figure down.#xD Asked whether the Government will be changing its advice for pregnant healthcare workers in light of the death of Mary Agyeiwaa Agyapong, Mr Hancock said: #xCThe first thing is to say that we work very closely with the Royal Colleges and whether guidance comes from the Royal Colleges, Public Health England or the NHS, we try to ensure that guidance comes from the most appropriate body for that particular group and we work very closely together.#xD:The Government’s six-element “battle plan” in combating spread of the virusGiving his evidence to the Health and Social Care Committee this morning, Matt Hancock outlined the Government#xs six-element #xCbattle plan#xD in combating the spread of the virus. He described the first, social distancing measures, as #xCmission critical#xD, alongside the second part of the plan of building up NHS capacity. #xCAs of this morning, we have the highest figure again of spare UK-wide critical care beds, of ,,#xD he said. #xCAnd of course the NHS Nightingale project, which has seen unbelievable roll-out, is a critical part of making sure we have always got NHS capacity.#xD Mr Hancock said the third part was supply of equipment, fourth part supply of testing and the fth part on treatments and vaccines. On the fth part, he told the committee: #xCThe more that we can do on treatments the less dangerous the disease is, and obviously on vaccines the UK is playing a world-leading role, but there is certainly still some time to go. #xCThe reason is because the mortality and morbidity is relatively low from this disease, terrible as the death toll is, the relative proportion of people who sadly die is relatively low.#xD After outlining the sixth path, which is shielding, Mr Hancock said: #xCOverall the goal is to bend the curve down and make sure the NHS capacity is there. #xCAnd at the same time to do the work to try to improve the ability of us as a society to cope with this disease and therefore with the goal that we can lt some of the incredibly restrictive measures we have to place on the population in order to get the disease under control.#xD :UK scientists believe Covid- outbreak may have started in SeptemberResearchers from the University of Cambridge have investigated the virus#x origin to calculate the likely date of the initial outbreak.Their findings indicate that the outbreak in Wuhan occurred between September  and December .Peter Forster, who led the study, said: #xCThe virus may have mutated into its final #xhuman-efficient#x form months ago, but stayed inside a bat or other animal or even human for several months without infecting other iniduals.#xCThen, it started infecting and spreading among humans between September  and December .#xDClick here for the full story.:KEY EVENTGovernment commits to publishing NHS staff death toll  times a weekHealth Secretary Matt Hancock said the official figure of NHS staff who have died from Coronavirus remains at .But he admitted the figure does not include Mary Agyeiwaa Agyapong, who died on Sunday.Mr Hancock said: #xCThe official veried figure remains , it gets updated  times a week and I will let you know as soon as I get an update.#xCSadly we#xve all seen reports of Mary the nurse who was pregnant and in the late stage of pregnancy, an NHS nurse, and died since the publication of the previous figures. So we know that the figure is higher.#xDHe committed to publishing the figure three times a week, adding: #xCI#xd like to get it to daily.#xD:EFL games likely to be played behind closed doorsEFL chief Rick Parry has written to supporters to inform them that matches are #xlikely#x to be played behind closed doors when the season can resume.Along with the Premier League and the vast majority of other competitions worldwide, the Championship and Leagues One and Two are on hold due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Parry admitted that it was impossible to put a date on a potential- but that it would probably involve matches taking place in empty grounds.The full story is here. :Number of deaths in care homes higher than %The number of deaths in care homes is higher than %, the health secretary has said. He is answering questions on Sky News this morning. :Health secretary says data outside of hospitals takes longer to collectMatt Hancock was asked on Sky News why it was only hospital deaths being recorded. The health secretary says: #xCData of deaths of people who have Covid- outside of hospitals takes longer to collect. #xCThat#xs because death certicates are written a couple of days after the death and then they can be registered.#xDIt is a data collection issue, he said.:Overall the goal is to bend the curve down, Matt Hancock saysOverall the goal is to bend the curve down and make sure NHS capacity is there, Matt Hancock says. He said we need to try to improve society#xs ability to cope with the disease. He thanked NHS staff and said he was grateful, and thanked the public who have followed rules leading to us now seeing the flattening of the curve. More OnCoronavirusWilliam and Kate

title: coronavirus testing kits could delivered
story: NewsCoronavirus testing kits could be delivered by Amazon with results sent by textPlans have reportedly been drawn up for a pilot program which will see Amazon deliver throat swabs to peoples homes that are picked up one hour later. Results will then be sent by text.ShareCommentsByElaine McCahillDeputy News Editor:,  APR NewsPlans have reportedly been drawn up to have coronavirus tests delivered to peoples homes " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus testing kits could be delivered to UK homes by Amazon with results being sent by text message within two days, it has been reported. The Times reports the company is starting a pilot program using Amazon logistics which will deliver throat swabs that are picked up one hour after a sample has been taken. Text messages will deliver the results, with the whole process aiming to wrap in less than  hours.The paper said the test was dferent from attempts to create a home test that shows antibodies to coronavirus.A spokesman for the Department of Health and Social Care did not confirm the report and neither did Amazonaposs press office when contacted. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. It comes as Health Secretary Matt Hancock prepares to face questions from MPs on Friday over the Governmentaposs coronavirus response, a day after lockdown measures were extended for at least another three weeks. Mr Hancock is expected to be quizzed on personal protective equipmentand an exit strategy as he appears before a virtual session of the Commons Health Committee. Meanwhile, the body which represents NHS biomedical scientists has said its members are still being held back from ramping up Covid- testing by a lack of kits, not a lack of capacity. The Institute of Biomedical Sciencesaid NHS labs were still struggling to source kits and reagents, and cast doubt on the ability to reach Mr Hancockaposs end-of-the-month target of , tests a day. The body also warned new mega-labs set up by the Government may end up competing with established NHS labs. Downing Street said on Thursday the UK now has the capacity to conduct , coronavirus tests a day - although fewer than half that number are currently being carried out. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said that in the  hours up to am on Wednesday, , tests were carried out across England, Scotland and Wales. Total testing capacity includes , in public facilities and a further , through commercial testing facilities. We have been very clear that where there is spare capacity available that should be used on NHS staff, on their families, and in social care, the spokesman said. IBMS president Allan Wilson said the issue within NHS labs was not capacity, but a lack of kits. The , NHS laboratory workers that I represent are increasingly expressing their frustration, he said in a statement. They have applied themselves innovatively to increase Covid- testing capacity and have the s ready so that the NHS laboratories are able to meet the Secretary of Stateaposs ambitious target, but they are still not able to source the testing kits and reagents they require. It concerns me when I see signicant investments being made in mass testing centres that are planning to conduct , of the , tests a day. These facilities would be a welcome resource and take pressure off the NHSthe issue around testing was one of capacity. However, we are clear that it is a global supply shortage holding biomedical scientists back, not a lack of capacity. Mr Wilson said there was concern mass testing centres may only serve to increase competition for what are already scarce supplies. He said NHS testing numbers could falllaboratories were competing with big testing centres for Covid- testing kits and reagents in a Wild West testing scenario.

story: NewsDad defying coronavirus lockdown with party told police he can do what he wantsCare worker Jamie Sparrow, , from Bolton, told police he was allowed to have a house party despite being ordered to break up the all-day gathering at his homeShareByThomas GeorgeLila Randall:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJamie Sparrow ignored lockdown and threw all-day house party " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man who held a party during the coronavirus lockdown told police he could aposdo what he wantsapos. Jamie Sparrow has appeared in court for breaching lockdown guidance after inviting a number of people to enjoy a barbecue and drink alcohol at his home in Kearsley, Bolton. Police were called to the house yesterday after a nurse who lived on the street reported the party, Manchester Evening News reports. A disturbance then broke out in the street after Sparrowaposs next-door neighbour Helen Bent directed a torrent of abuse at the woman who had complained.Bent, , and Sparrow, , were arrested and spent a night in the cells before appearing at Manchester Magistratesapos Court today.A judge was told police had been called to the party at the semi-detached property during the day. Despite a warning, the party continued late into the evening. When officers ed at pm, they found six people still inside the house - including a young child. Bent defied further orders to leave and, as other neighbours aired their concerns to officers in the street, the mother-of-three turned on the woman who had complained, calling her a aposfat f***ing s**gapos. She then stormed back inside the house and turned up the volume on the music while shouting apospartyapos.  Laura Keegan, prosecuting, said Sparrow, who works as a care worker at a childrenaposs home, then started behaving in an aposaggressive and argumentativeapos manner towards officers, who were forced to restrain him. The court heard the father-of-one did not aposseem to understand what social distancing isapos even when officers tried to explain it to him. Ms Keegan added: He told police he would do whatever he wants, when he wants. He said he was allowed to have a house party. Joseph Foxler, representing the pair in court, said Sparrow had consumed two glasses of rum, but was not a regular drinker. Bent had drunk eight cans of Carling in the build-up to the incident, but was said not to be drunk. The pair pleaded guilty to charges of a breach of peace and contravening a requirement as to restriction of movement.

title: government slammed shambolic bid supply
story: NewsGovernment slammed for shambolic bid to supply carers with coronavirus PPEA leaked letter from the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services said Britains care sector was being overlooked while officials focused on the NHS during the Covid- crisisShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editorRhian Lubin:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAE nurse Mark Boothroyd is one of the NHS staff protesting the lack of PPE" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCare bosses have accused ministers of a “shambolic” attempt to supply frontline workers with personal protective equipment. Leaders from the industry said they were receiving only “paltry” and “haphazard” deliveries of lesaving items such as masks, gloves and gowns. It added that carers have been forced to go without such items while they have been mandatory for all healthcare workers. Meanwhile, NHS staff have taken part in protests to highlight the failings in PPE provision and are calling on Health Secretary Matt Hancock to resign.  They launched a protest on social media yesterday, backed by campaign group Keep Our NHS Public, to coincide with the pm Clap for our Carers. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Their campaign states: “As we see our colleagues die, we have lost confidence in the Government.” Mark Boothroyd, , an AE nurse at London’s St Thomas’s Hospital, where Boris Johnson was treated, said: “We’re all fed up with not having enough PPE or not good enough quality PPE, it’s putting us at risk. We feel we’re being lied to.  “The government is trying to blame us for their failings and it’s our safety - and our lives - on the line. “We’re seeing the government telling everyone it’s fine and it’s going to be ok - it is not. We know it’s not. “St Thomas’s is one of the best hospitals in the country and we only have enough high quality PPE for our ICUs and Resus - and we’re just about scraping by on the wards. “We don’t have enough gowns for doing personal care with patients. In the community the situation is even more dire and they are really struggling.” The explosive letter was sent to the Government by the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services and leaked to the BBC. It adds: “Testing for care workers appears to be being rolled out without being given thought to who is going to be tested and what we are going to do with the result.” It said the care sector, which looks after around , of Britain’s most vulnerable people, was being overlooked while officials focused on the NHS.  The letter said staff had been left confused and faced extra work because of mixed messages put out by officials. It also criticised the Government for recruiting , NHS volunteers and then giving them “nothing to do”. Care bosses believe these people were erted from volunteering with the elderly in their local communities. Shadow Care Minister Liz Kendall said: “The concerns raised in this letter are extremely worrying. Their view that the supply chain for PPE has been shambolic and that testing for care workers hasn’t been properly thought through must be an urgent wake-up call for ministers. “ Coronavirus has exposed the already fragile state of these vital services. Ministers must heed the warnings from Adass and take all necessary action to halt the emerging crisis in social care.” Facing growing pressure to act, Mr Hancock on Wednesday promised measures to alleviate the dire situation in the nation’s , care homes.  He vowed to raise the amount of personal protective kit given to homes and to offer testing to all residents and staff with symptoms. Mr Hancock yesterday said he was confident only % homes – or one in six – had outbreaks. However, robust data from across Europe showed around half of care homes have Covid- cases. Care providers estimate up to two thirds of English care homes have outbreaks. Adass said it was “disappointed” that the letter was leaked publicly, but said the issues addressed “were already in the public domain and a cause of considerable concern”. President Julie Ogley said: “Some of the language used in the letter  may be more emotional than we would normally use, but we are in emotional times.  “We see continuing concerns about access to PPE, availability of testing, rising numbers of Covid-  cases  in care homes and people are sadly dying. “It is vital we prioritise people who are using social care, family carers and staff, whether in care homes or their own homes, to protect them. We are pleased the Government’s strategy is a positive response to many of the concerns that we have raised.” A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: “The Government has set out a comprehensive action plan to support the adult social care sector in England throughout the coronavirus outbreak, including ramping up testing, overhauling the way PPE is being delivered to care homes, and helping to minimise the spread of the virus.

story: NewsHow Leonard Nipper Read did what no-one  could do - put the Kray twins behind barsEXCLUSIVE: Detective Leo­­nard “Nipper” Read died from coronavirus last week aged , as we take a look back at how he managed to put the notorious pair behind barsShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsLeonard Nipper Read " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDusk had fallen over HM Prison Brixton when a short, shy vicar passed through security and made his way to the jail chapel.        Inmates barely noticed as the dog-collared holy man, Bible in hand, shuffled past their cells. He was, however, no priest but undercover police detective Leo­­nard “Nipper” Read about to finally take down the most feared gang in London’s history. While pretending to hear the con­­­fessions of a sinner, he instead took a secret statement from the Kray twins’ trusted right-hand man that would put them behind bars for the rest of their lives.  Nipper, widely regarded as the greatest policeman of post-war Britain, died last week at  – another victim of coronavirus.Author James Morton, who wrote Nipper Read: The Man Who Nicked the Krays with the legendary detective, says his friend had “a good and remarkable le”. “He did what no one  man­­aged – to put the Krays behind bars. He was honest and trustworthy at a time when a great many in the Met were not so honest. He was a thoroughly genuine, decent man. As a crime author, I’ve spoken to a lot of criminals who knew and respected him. “The we of one robber he helped convict told me he was the perfect gentleman in every way.”  Nipper shouldn’t actually have been allowed to join the police at all. Too small at ft in – hence his nickname – he failed the entrance criteria for the force in his home city of Nottingham. He was only accepted by the Met after convincing the medical examiner he was still growing, at the age of , and promising to perform daily “stretching” exercises. But his short stature proved invaluable. He admitted: “I was very small and very thin and didn’t look anything like a policeman”.  It came in useful many times as he went under cover and he was soon sent to CID. Early attempts to put Ronnie and Reggie behind bars ended in disaster as their violent reputation made witnesses afraid to testy. So Nipper’s new boss, Assistant Commissioner Peter Brodie, tasked him with bringing down the organised crime bosses once and for all. Nipper later remembered being astonished at the celebrity status of the Krays in London’s East End.  He said: “If they drove down Commercial Road every­­one waved. “If somebody had a drink with them, it was like having tea with Princess Margaret.” As an undercover officer, he first saw Ronnie Kray in  at the Grave Maurice pub in Whitechapel. He said: “There was a big American car and a guy stepped out with his hand in his pocket as though he had a gun there and sort of swept the street, making sure there was no one in sight. He gave a signal, the door opened and out stepped Ronnie.  “He was dressed like a s Chicago gangster with a cashmere coat that reached to his ankles tied with a loose belt at the waist. His hair was greased and parted and he wore glasses. “He looked like Al Capone without his fedora.” Convinced they were untouchable, the Krays’ gang The Firm were responsible for a string of gruesome murders in  and . In the first, Ronnie shot George Cornell in the head in front of locals in the Blind Beggar pub because he had referred to him as “a fat poof”. Another victim, Jack “the Hat” McVitie, was lured to a basement where he was held down in a chair as Reggie sliced his face with broken glass before stabbing him with a carving kne in the face and neck and twisting the kne. Nipper knew that,he wanted to catch the biggest fish of all, he would have to do things dferently, explains Mr Morton.  He says: “The Krays were getting away with it because their solicitor’s clerk knew certain people in the Met who they were paying off. “The story was thatyou went in to make a statement about the Krays, by the time you came out the brothers already had a copy.” Nipper began approaching fringe members of The Firm, persuading them to spill the beans in exchange for immunity. Knowing there were few officers he could trust, he revealed as little of his investigations as possible. Even so, the Krays got wind he was after them. They bought two boa constrictors and named them Read and Gerrard after Nipper and his partner Fred Gerrard.Eventually Nipper had enough to charge the Krays with fraudand grievous bodily harm and, in May , the twins, along with brother Charlie and their lieutenant Albert Donoghue, were dragged from their beds and arrested in a dawn raid. With the ringleaders behind bars, Nipper set to work persuading key witnesses, include the barmaid of the pub where George Cornell was shot dead and Leslie Payne, who had handled the Kray’s business affairs, to testy against them. Mr Morton says: “The barmaid was terried. So he played a long and patient game, taking her and her children to Lon­­­don airport to see the planes and slowly persuading her she did not need to be afraid.” But at Brix­­­ton prison, the Krays were planning to pin the mur­­ders on other gang members, inc­­luding Donoghue. But he got wind of it and sent a message, via his mother, that he wanted to speak to Nipper.  This was when the detective dressed as a vicar and met Donoghue in the jail chapel. Mr Morton says: “Donoghue said ‘I’ll tell you everything’. And he did. That was the moment the Krays’ empire came crashing down.” The following year the twins were sen­­tenced to le with a mini­­mum  years – the longest murder sen­­tences ever handed down at the Old Bailey. Ronnie died aged  in Broadmoor in  and Reggie in , eight weeks after being released on compassionate grounds. Nipper retired in , having received the Queen’s Police Medal the previous year, and became national security adviser to the National Museums and Galleries Commission.

However, he appeared to downplay any link to the ongoing pandemic at the time, making no reference to it at a groundbreaking ceremony and instead linking its completion to a national holiday. But now it looks like the project might be rushed to completion even sooner.Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirrorAccording to state run media, builders are intent on completing construction “faster and better”, and are working “day and night” to get the hospital up and running. The report added that the “vicious” sanctions imposed by “hostile forces” to punish North Korea for its nuclear weapons programme were having no impact on progress. New images show that foundations had already been dug, concrete poured and metal structural supports installed.  In one photo construction can be seen continuing at night. The reason for the renewed urgency is not stated in the report, but experts agree that the building is coming together quickly. Martyn Williams and Peter Makoswky from North Korea watchdog,  North, analysed the project in satellite photos.  “Construction has continued at such pace that for the first time – after just under one month – the overall outline of the building is visible,” they wrote. “Commercial satellite imagery from April  shows clear outlines of the two towers that will dominate the rear of the hospital. “The rest of the building is also taking shape, including a distinctive lip that juts out from the front of the hospital.”  North Korea’s two closest neighbours have had tens of thousands of coronavirus cases, but the Kim regime says there has not been a single one within its borders. The claim cannot be independently veried in the closed-off country and has been met with scepticism.

How do we know when we have reached the peak  Prof Martin McKee, professor of European Public Health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: “First, we are still testing many fewer people than in our European neighbours. But that may be because fewer people are now being referred to hospitals as GPs are using clinical protocols to decide who will benefit from hospital treatment and who is too frail to be sent to hospital, and a lot of people are dying at home. In care homes too, we know there are a lot of deaths but we don’t know how many. How many days beyond the peak will lockdown start to be lted  Around two weeks after the reproduction number has fallen below , according to Prof McKee. But he cautioned: “Only when we are confident about the accuracy of the data can we begin thinking about loosening the lockdown. Also, this is absolutely dependent on having a robust system for testing and contact tracing in place.” How might the Government go about lting restrictions  Prof McKee said: “Firstly, we can ease the restrictions very gradually, for example, open only certain types of shops. The second thing is to put in place mechanisms to reduce spread, which will certainly include continued physical distancing.” Dr Ashton believes measures could first be eased off in parts of the country which have registered fewer cases. He said: “There don’t seem to be a lot of deaths in South West England, East Anglia and Lincolnshire and the main parts of Wales. “We could begin to relax restrictions in those places and adopt the same approach as we started with, testing, contract tracing and isolating those who test positive.”  But, again, he warned easing lockdown will only worktesting is massively ramped up. Could the schools be reopened soon  Denmark has relaxed restrictions on eduction, with children up to the age of  ing to nurseries and schools this week. But Dr Ashton is not convinced. He said: “Schoolkids are good at spreading viruses, so I don’t understand the talk about reopening schools.” Could younger workers who live alone be first back to work  Dr Ashton believes “creative solutions” must be found. He said: “I’ve been arguing that we should be billeting essential workers and volunteers away from anyone who is susceptible to the virus, and that might mean taking over hotels and boarding houses to allow them to live a normal le.”  Prof McKee, however, is sceptical of allowing some under a certain age toto work and prohibiting others. Which shops might be allowed to open first  Dr Ashton says: “If you want to stop people mixing then you don’t want places where people are sitting next to each other. However, you might want to open drinks and food retailers offering only takeaway or carry home services, but I still think that’s still some way off.” Could office and factory workers be tested before work  Prof McKee said: “The logistical challenges would be enormous, not least because it does take time to do the tests.”  Dr Ashton believes that regular testing such workers will be crucial. He says: “One option might be to test them all before they are allowed back, then screen their temperatures several times a day.” Aren’t other countries beginning toto normal  Prof McKee points out Spain is only moving to a position which is still more restrictive than in the UK. He adds: “In Italy, only a few shops, such as bookshops and those selling children’s clothing are being allowed to open in some regions.” Once the measures are lted, might they have to be reinstated   “Yes,” says Prof McKee. “Restrictions cannot be considered permanent until we have actually got this virus under control.” When will I be able to see my elderly relatives in a care home or self-isolating at home  Dr Ashton says: “It will be a long time before you will be able to see your relatives face to face, until we’re absolutely clear what’s going on. People will have to find ways to care for and love their relatives without being there in person, and make sure they can speak to them via videoconferencing.”  Prof McKee agrees, but warns: “We need to think very carefully about how we support those people who are confined.” Until a vaccine is developed, how might le remain dferent  Prof McKee said: “I think people will be very cautious about ing to anything like normality. This will have huge implications for how we live our lives, including the places we meet and shop, and for leisure, in particular where we go on holiday.” Dr Ashton says he doubts any of us will be able to go abroad for our summer holidays.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A person with coronavirus could infect others around them simply by saying one or two words in a calm and normal voice, a new study suggests.When a Covid- carrier speaks, they emit tiny liquid droplets that contain infectious virus particles and could linger in the air - and be inhaled by others - for up to three hours, research has found. The droplets behave like an aerosol - a suspension of particles or droplets in air or another gas - and can penetrate deep into the lungs when they are breathed in, scientists found. A team from the US National Institutes of Health used a laser light-scattering experiment to demonstrate how droplets fill the air when a person speaks, and how masks can block them and prevent the spread of Covid-. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror.  The study was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Molecular biologist Dr Matthew Meselson, of Hard University, wrote: Certain persons called apossuper spreadersapos produce many more aerosol particles than other persons. These particles are too small to settle because of gravity, but they are carried by air currents and dispersed by dfusion and air turbulence. Inhaled aerosolised particles can penetrate deep into the lungs and infect cells in the alveoli, air sacs in the lungs which exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules to and from the bloodstream, the study found. The particles can be carried by drafts. Dr Meselson added: Aerosols from infected persons may therefore pose an inhalation threat even at considerable distances and in enclosed spaces, particularlythere is poor ventilation. The possible contribution of infective aerosols to the current pandemic suggests the advisability of wearing a suitable mask whenever it is thought that infected persons may be nearby and of providing adequate ventilation of enclosed spaces where such persons are known to be or may recently have been. The researchers said some studies have shown that the number of droplets produced by speaking is similar to the number produced by coughing.Masks can prevent the droplets from filling the air, the scientists said. A separate study in the New England Journal of Medicine in March found that aerosolised coronavirus could remain in the air for up to three hours.

story: NewsYouve been holding your burgers wrong, according to a scientistA group of researchers who specialise in fluid mechanics, engineering, and dentistry have demonstrated the ideal way to hold a burger in order to make minimum messShareCommentsByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  APR NewsEating a burger can get a little messy " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnyone who loves a burger will know just how messy they can be, unless you eat it plain. Now, a typical burger consists of a beef patty, lettuce, tomato, cheese and onion - and whatever sauce tickles your fancy, letaposs say tomato ketchup and mustard for argumentaposs sake. You only have to take one bite for most of the filling to fall out and the sauce to be dripping half way down your chin - not ideal. But, it doesnapost have to be that way anymore. A group of researchers who specialise in fluid mechanics, engineering, and dentistry have claimed that in fact, there is a right way and a wrong way to hold and eat a massive burger without it falling to pieces.  They demonstrated their elaborate findings after four months of research on the Japanese television showHonma Dekka! .The episode isnapost new, itaposs actually from , but has resurfaced and been doing the rounds on social media once again during lockdown. On the show, a scan of the burger shows how each of the filling elements interact with each other. Then it shows how a person usually holds a burger, with their thumbs on the bottom bun and the rest of their fingers supporting the top bun.  What this does is squeeze all of the fillings out of the sides of the bun. The researchers then tried holding a burger in numerous ways, to see which way resulted in the least amount of spillage. Hereaposs what they concluded. How it should be done, according to the experts When you pick up your burger, you must make sure that youaposre not holding it too tight - this is vital. Subconsciously we do this when we take a bite, perhaps in the hopes that the harder we squeeze it, the higher the chances weaposve got in keeping it together. But all this does is crushes your burger, and forces the fillings to spill out.  Before you take your very first bite, the dentist explains that you should try opening your mouth wide and closing it again to warm up the muscles. And, the best way to hold it is to put your thumbs and pinkie fingers at the bottom, and your other three fingers on top in a claw like position. Your pinkies will affectively hold the back portion of the bun together so the contents wonapost fall out.
